raw_text: Here a small number of components per word are assumed, which makes the approaches difficult to apply as such to agglutinative languages. We previously presented two segmentation algorithms suitable for agglutinative languages (Creutz and Lagus, 2002)
clean_text: We previously presented two segmentation algorithms suitable for agglutinative languages (Creutz and Lagus, 2002).

raw_text: A Poisson distribution can be justified and has been used in order to model the length distribution of word and morph tokens [e.g., (Creutz and Lagus, 2002)], but for morph types we have chosen the gamma distribution, which has a thicker tail
clean_text: A Poisson distribution can be justified and has been used in order to model the length distribution of word and morph tokens [e.g., (Creutz and Lagus, 2002)], but for morph types we have chosen the gamma distribution, which has a thicker tail.

raw_text: The search for the optimal model given our input data corresponds closely to the recursive segmentation algorithm presented in (Creutz and Lagus, 2002)
clean_text: The search for the optimal model given our input data corresponds closely to the recursive segmentation algorithm presented in (Creutz and Lagus, 2002).

raw_text: We utilize an evaluation method for segmentation of words presented in (Creutz and Lagus, 2002)
clean_text: We utilize an evaluation method for segmentation of words presented in (Creutz and Lagus, 2002).

citing_paper_authors: Jeremy, Nicholson | Trevor, Cohn | Timothy, Baldwin
raw_text: For highly inflecting languages more generally, morphological analysis is often treated as a segment and-normalise problem, amenable to analysis by weighted finite state transducer (wFST), for example, Creutz and Lagus (2002) for Finnish
clean_text: For highly inflecting languages more generally, morphological analysis is often treated as a segment and-normalise problem, amenable to analysis by weighted finite state transducer (wFST), for example, Creutz and Lagus (2002) for Finnish.

raw_text: Creutz and Lagus (2002) proposed two unsupervised methods for word segmentation, one based on maximum description length, and one based on maximum likelihood
clean_text: Creutz and Lagus (2002) proposed two unsupervised methods for word segmentation, one based on maximum description length, and one based on maximum likelihood.

raw_text: Morfessor Baseline (Creutz and Lagus, 2002): This is a public baseline algorithm based on jointly minimizing the size of the morph codebook and the encoded size of the all the word forms using the minimum description length MDL cost function
clean_text: Morfessor Baseline (Creutz and Lagus, 2002): This is a public baseline algorithm based on jointly minimizing the size of the morph codebook and the encoded size of all the word forms using the minimum description length MDL cost function.

raw_text: Among others ,de Marcken (1996), Brent (1999), Goldsmith (2001), Creutz and Lagus (2002), and Creutz (2006) have shown that models based onthe above approach produce segmentations that resemble linguistic morpheme segmentations, when formulated mathematically in a probabilistic framework or equivalently using the Minimum Description Length (MDL) principle (Rissanen, 1989)
